title: Beginner Course in the Development of the Tourism Industry
headline: Learn how the travel and tourist activities of the past have led to the creation of the modern day tourist industry.
description: This free online course on the development of the tourist industry will teach you all about the formation of the tourism industry, from ancient times to the modern era. The tourism sector didn't just develop overnight, they have a fascinating and important global history. Tourism and travel are incredibly rewarding activities and powerful industries that lie at the heart of several modern economies across the world.
courseDescription:
In order to understand the present and prepare for the future, one must first learn what happened in the past. This course begins by showing you how travel developed in ancient and medieval times and proceeds by detailing the evolution of travel both in Europe and the United States. It will then explain how the modern tourist industry is influenced by the tourist habits of the past.

Different modes of transportation have gradually developed throughout history. This course will explain how transportation influences people's vacation habits. It will also explain how accommodation for travelers has advanced since the Middle Ages. You will then learn about the importance of three central factors that people consider when making decisions about their vacation. You will also learn about the two financial aspects of potential tourists and discover how Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs can be used to promote tourism effectively.

Tourism has become one of the biggest industries globally generating up to 10% of the world's GDP. Many countries consider tourism as one of their top priorities because of the benefits it brings. This makes people with knowledge and skills in tourism highly valuable members of any economy, with employment opportunities around the world. With this course, you can boost your knowledge of this vital industry and get a little closer to an excellent career, all for free.

Start Course Now

• Module One Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Explain how the history of travel evolved in ancient and medieval times.
    • Outline the development of travel in Europe since the Renaissance.
    • Discuss the history of travel in the United States since the 18th century.
    • Describe how advancements in transportation led to the popularization of tourism throughout history.
    • Trace how the modern tourist industry is influenced by tourism in the past.

    • People have always traveled. This unit will explain why and how people in ancient and medieval times traveled and how this has influenced our modern conceptions of travelling.

      In ancient times people tended to remain settled in one place for practical reasons. Travel was sometimes necessary, to for example, seek food or to escape some danger. 

      Gradually, larger settlements of people developed along coastal areas and beside rivers, largely for food and sanitary purposes. This led to the development of water craft. Boats began to be used to travel - sometimes quite long distances, to other settlements, essentially to trade.
      People have always traveled. This unit will explain why and how people in ancient and medieval times traveled and how this has influenced our modern conceptions of travelling.

      Gradually, larger settlements of people developed along coastal areas and beside rivers, largely for food and sanitary purposes. This led to the development of water craft. Boats began to be used to travel - sometimes quite long distances, to other settlements, essentially to trade.
    • The development of towns, cities and commerce led to the creation of empires. This led to more and more trade and more and more travel. 

      The first empire nation with considerable need for travel was Egypt. At the peak of the Egyptian Empire, travel flourished, for business and for pleasure. Travel satisfied people's curiosity. As early as 2700 BC, writers noted that people would come to visit the tombs constructed by the early pharaohs. 

      It is notable that there are accounts of people taking stone chippings with them as they left the tombs. This behaviour mirrors modern people's fondness for returning from a trip with a souvenir.

    • The Renaissance began a new age of enlightenment in Europe. This period saw people travelling purely to experience higher culture for the first time in centuries. 

      This unit will explain how upper-class cultural tourists' developed tourism from the Renaissance onwards. It will also explain how the military conflicts of Western Europe indirectly influenced modern tourist activities. 

      Finally, it will detail how the industrial revolution began an era in which middle and working class people could take annual holidays.

      The impetus to travel in order to learn was aided by the arrival of Renaissance works from Italy. Furthermore, the relatively stable monarchical hierarchy of Europe helped assure travellers' safety.

      The next important factor in the post-Roman development of travel was the Renaissance. As society moved from a rural to an urban base, wealth grew and more people had the money to travel. 

      Pilgrimages were still important, although journeys to Jerusalem declined because of the growth of Protestantism in Europe. 

      The impetus to travel in order to learn was aided by the arrival of Renaissance works from Italy. Furthermore, the relatively stable monarchical hierarchy of Europe helped assure travellers' safety.

    • As in Europe, travel in the the United States of America began developing in the 18th century. 

      America's tourist culture was defined by the same factors as Europe's: the methods of transport available, the vacation habits of the wealthy and the advancement of workers' rights during industrialization.

      Construction of the railway opened up the entire country to travel. The Erie Railroad led to Niagara Falls becoming a popular honeymoon resort by the 1870's. 

      The vast river network in the interior of the nation, led to extensive steamboat travel and people went on gambling and amusement trips between New Orleans, Louisiana and St Louis, Missouri.

• Lesson Summary

    • Ancient people living in coastal areas and beside rivers, used watercraft to travel to other settlements to trade.
    • The first Empire nation with greater needs for travel was Egypt (military, trade, religious). People would travel to visit the tombs of the Pharaohs from as early as 2700 BC.
    • The Assyrian military developed primitive roads and traveled by chariot and on horseback.
    • The Persian Empire invented the four-wheeled carriage for the wealthy.
    • The first expansive travel infrastructure was developed during the Greek empire. Greeks would travel to other cities by boat to trade; a distribution network evolved.
    • Travel in Ancient Greece was advanced by the use of currency (money) and the ubiquity of the Greek language.
    • The Roman Empire developed a large middle class with the money to travel and sightseeing became popular.
    • In the 12th century, large numbers of people went on pilgrimages to different Christian ('holy') sites. 
    • During the Renaissance, people with curiosity and money travelled around Europe to experience different cultures.
    • The Grand Tour was a Renaissance concept, in which young upper-class men accompanied ambassadors (tutors) throughout Europe in order to complete their education.

• Module Two Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • List the modes of transport used throughout history and explain how they influenced people's vacationing habits.
    • Describe how accommodation for travellers has developed since the middle ages.
    • Discuss the three main influences on people's decisions to go on vacation.
    • Summarize how time, since the industrial revolution, has effected people's decisions to travel.
    • Outline the financial considerations of potential tourists. 
    • Trace how Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs has been used to market tourism.

    • Stagecoaches were invented in Hungary in the 15th century. The word coach comes from the Hungarian town of Kocs. The first coaches were closed carriages suspended on leather straps between four wheels. The straps acted as suspension to compensate for the poor condition of the roads.

      The need to rest horses every few kilometres led to the development of posting houses where the animals could drink and eat. Posting houses also provided food and accommodation for travellers. The poor state of most roads meant that travel was very uncomfortable. Posting houses offered stagecoach travellers a place to rest. Over time posting houses evolved into taverns.

    • A major development in travel by road came in the early nineteenth century, when John McAdam and Thomas Telford invented a new type of road surface that greatly improved the common dirt roads found throughout Europe.

      The technique consisted of laying small broken stones (gravel) on the ground and ensuring that there was suitable drainage on each side of the road. It is said that McAdam insisted that no stone be used if it could not fit into the mouth of the labourer laying it down. The roads created with this method were much more comfortable to travel on by stagecoach.

    • From the middle ages until the 17th century, travellers would be invited into people's homes as they made their long journeys. People felt an obligation to house travellers and treat them well.  

      As the numbers of travellers increased with modes of mass transport, specific buildings were erected to house travellers.

      The first hostelries, called ordinaries, began appearing in mid-17th century colonial America. They later evolved into inns. An ordinary usually consisted of two small rooms. One room had a bar (dining room) and was used for eating and drinking; the other room was reserved for the landlord and his family. Travellers slept on the floor of the bar/dining room.

    • There are many things a person needs to consider before deciding to take a holiday. This unit will explain the three most important factors in people's decision to take a vacation. These factors are: Time, money and motivation.

      People spend their time in one of three ways: at work, engaged in necessary tasks or at leisure. Prior to the industrial revolution, people lived in rural areas and worked on the land. The way in which they spent their free time was primarily influenced by the weather. During the industrial revolution, more and more people moved to the cities for work.

      Factory owners insisted that employees work 12 hours a day, 6 days a week. Their only day off was the Sabbath day. People were so tired and paid so little, that they had neither the energy nor the money to do much with their leisure time. Furthermore, people at this time still believed that one should rest on the Sabbath day.

    • During the industrial revolution, holidays were infrequent and unpaid. It wasn't until the rise of trade unions in the 1920s and 1930s that workers began to receive paid vacations. 

      Today, the average workweek is less than 40 hours and paid vacation is standard. In the UK, 21 days of paid holidays are standard. In the United States, Germany and Sweden workers have up to 40 days paid leisure time per year.
       
      Today, time is considered a precious commodity and lack of time is one of the biggest barriers to taking a holiday. This is especially true in two-income families as two work schedules must find an opening to travel. However, as both parents now work, vacationing is seen as an invaluable opportunity for the family to spend quality time together.

      People spend their time in one of three ways: at work, engaged in necessary tasks or at leisure. Prior to the industrial revolution, people lived in rural areas and worked on the land. The way in which they spent their free time was primarily influenced by the weather. During the industrial revolution, more and more people moved to the cities for work.

      Factory owners insisted that employees work 12 hours a day, 6 days a week. Their only day off was the Sabbath day. People were so tired and paid so little, that they had neither the energy nor the money to do much with their leisure time. Furthermore, people at this time still believed that one should rest on the Sabbath day. 
    • During the industrial revolution, holidays were infrequent and unpaid. It wasn't until the rise of trade unions in the 1920s and 1930s that workers began to receive paid vacations. 

      Today, the average workweek is less than 40 hours and paid vacation is standard. In the UK, 21 days of paid holidays are standard. In the United States, Germany and Sweden workers have up to 40 days paid leisure time per year.
       
      Today, time is considered a precious commodity and lack of time is one of the biggest barriers to taking a holiday. This is especially true in two-income families as two work schedules must find an opening to travel. However, as both parents now work, vacationing is seen as an invaluable opportunity for the family to spend quality time together.

• Lesson Summary

    • Stagecoaches were invented in Hungary in the 15th century. The need to rest horses every few kilometres led to the development of posting houses.
    • In the early 19th century John McAdam and Thomas Telford invented a new type of road surface that greatly improved the roads of Europe.
    • The American model of long distance rail travel provided inspiration for mainland Europe. The first railway was opened in England in 1825. 
    • Rail was the most popular form of transport for approximately 100 years, from the 1830s to the 1930s.
    • Competition from cars, buses and air travel has caused a steady decline in travel by train.
    • The advent of the ocean liner, in the early 19th century, enabled large numbers of commuters to travel from Europe to America.
    • The first regular and reliable ocean liner service was the RMS Britannia, which had its maiden voyage in 1840.
    • The rise of air travel, following WW2, led to a dramatic fall in the number of people travelling by ocean liner.
    • The popularisation of cars, in the 20th century, led to tourist destinations becoming more dispersed. Motor Hotels (Motels) began to appear all across America from the 1950s.
    • Hostelries, (also called 'ordinaries'), were the first kind of paid accommodation available for travelers, from the mid-17th century. Hostelries later evolved into Inns.

    • There are five major attractions that draw people to a particular destination. These are:

      1. Natural Features
      2. Visit Friends/Relatives
      3. Ethnicity/Culture
      4. Entertainment

    • Every destination has its own unique characteristics that distinguish it from other locations and make it a desirable tourist destination.

      Weather is one of the most defining features of a region. For many tourists, it is the main reason they choose to holiday in a certain place. Tourist resorts will use their climate to their own advantage, in order to attract tourists.

      Tourists often desire a holiday location that has a different climate to that in their home country. This can be seen in Europe where tourists from the Mediterranean region will travel to Alpine ski resorts and tourists from colder regions will travel to Spain and Italy for sunshine.

    • Whatever the motivation is for travelling to a destination, visitors will need certain amenities during their stay. Amenities themselves are not the cause of a destination being popular. However, they contribute to ensuring that the destination continues to be popular. The major amenities required by visitors are: accommodation; restaurants and cafs; services and infrastructure.

      Accommodation accounts for 20%-25% of total tourist expenditure. To be successful, a destination needs a sufficient variety of accommodation to appeal to all types of visitors with varying budgets and requirements.

      Campsites and caravan parks are consistently popular with city dwellers who seek a break from urban life. Campsites are also popular with young families, as they provide plenty of space and activities for children. 
      Whatever the motivation is for travelling to a destination, visitors will need certain amenities during their stay. Amenities themselves are not the cause of a destination being popular. However, they contribute to ensuring that the destination continues to be popular. The major amenities required by visitors are: accommodation; restaurants and cafs; services and infrastructure.

      Accommodation accounts for 20%-25% of total tourist expenditure. To be successful, a destination needs a sufficient variety of accommodation to appeal to all types of visitors with varying budgets and requirements.

    • Since the early 1990s, a number of luxury campsites have opened. These offer private, chalet-style accommodation and include room service, en suite washrooms and food services. Such resorts appeal to people that would like to stay in open countryside and still have the amenities of a hotel. 

      Tourist destinations should also have a variety of bed and breakfasts (B&Bs). B&Bs appeal to budget conscious travellers who do not wish to pay for a hotel. Tourist areas should also contain guesthouses. Guesthouses are essentially luxury bed and breakfasts and charge a similar fee to hotels. Their appeal lies in the fact that they offer guests personalised service. 

      While other forms of accommodation are popular with tourists, most travellers prefer to stay in hotels. Today, hotel chains dominate the marketplace and each chain targets certain profiles of customers. There are three main types of hotel chains; budget, mainstream and luxury.

    • An essential element of tourism is a functioning transport system. The existence of tourism is based on the desire to travel to different places and be able to get around and explore when there. 

      Most travellers want their destination to be exotic and noticeably different from their home. Today, tourists do not mind travelling great distances to destinations, as long as they can travel quickly and comfortably.

      Having an effective transport network ensures that tourists are able to travel to destinations. Transport networks are evaluated according to: convenience, time and cost.

    • One of the first things people evaluate when considering travel, is how convenient is it to travel there? If two prospective destinations are similar, tourists are likely to travel to the closest one. For example, a couple from the north-eastern United States are more likely to travel to Florida than to California for a sun holiday. 

      Some destinations may be relatively close to tourists but take more time and effort to reach. For example, some destinations may not receive direct flights from the tourist's local airport. Also, connection flights often involve extensive layovers and add to the cost of travelling.

• Lesson Summary

    • There are five main attractions that draw people to particular destinations: Natural landscape; Visit friends/relatives; Ethnic roots/cultural; Entertainment; Weather.
    • Every destination has its own unique characteristics that distinguish it from others and make it a desirable location.
    • Tourist locations can offer permanent and temporary entertainment. Permanent entertainment is available at all times, for example casinos in Las Vegas. Temporary entertainment is available for a limited duration, for example the Winter Olympics.
    • The primary amenities required by tourists are: accommodation; restaurants/cafs; services (laundry, groceries, medical, internet etc.) and infrastructure (water, roads, police etc.)
    • Accommodation accounts for approx. 20%-25% of a tourist's expenditure.
    • To be successful, tourist destinations should have a variety of types of accommodation and attractions that appeal to all types of visitors.
    • Types of visitors include: groups of young men and women; people travelling alone; older people; couples; families. 
    • Tourists tend to spend most of their holiday budget on food and drink.
